QuoteText: Parcum's terminology may be a little off. Ephebophelia may be due to homosexuality in the priesthood even if pedophilia is not. Most of the cases of the scandal were ephebophilia. . . .
ResponseText: Again, I salute you, Maximus, the Jesuitical application of the word "ephebophilia," which I have also seen used by a high official in the Roman Catholic Church hoping to triviliaze pedophilia in the Church by calling it "ephebophilia," and urging that this be considered a lesser crime--if, indeed, a crime at all.

Just out of curiosity, on what issue is the Catholic Church not unfit to rule on? The Catholic Church provides plenty of rules on all sorts of behavior as well as position statements on all kinds of political and social issues ranging from poverty to war to the death penalty and the church has certainly sided with the political left as well as the political right depending on the issue. So I would ask those of you who support a woman's right to choose the following questions: a) Would it make any difference to you if the Catholic Church's record on pedophilia was 100% clean and b) Would it make a difference to you if the Church's stated position was more favorable to your own?

QuoteText: Just out of curiosity, on what issue is the Catholic Church not unfit to rule on? . . . So I would ask those of you who support a woman's right to choose the following questions: a) Would it make any difference to you if the Catholic Church's record on pedophilia was 100% clean and b) Would it make a difference to you if the Church's stated position was more favorable to your own?
ResponseText: I would certainly respect the Catholic Church a great deal more as a moral arbiter if this were the case. I don't expect that the Church should have a stated position that is more favorable to my own--at least not at the present time. The Church has historically vacillated on the issue of abortion, which is to be expected in any human institution. I do expect, however, in future times, that when the Church has made priesthood available to the female sex and leadership roles in the Church are assumed by women, that the Church's stance on abortion will change. Such affairs are not within my province. I will only have difficulties with the Church when it intrudes into the private business and sexual lives of women who are not Roman Catholics--as it presently does.
female roles wont change it....It is a set of beliefs not a sex that determines how you feel about abortion. My beloved Episcopal Church does not support abortion and I have a female rector.

QuoteText: .... I don't expect that the Church should have a stated position that is more favorable to my own--at least not at the present time. The Church has historically vacillated on the issue of abortion, which is to be expected in any human institution. I do expect, however, in future times, that when the Church has made priesthood available to the female sex and leadership roles in the Church are assumed by women, that the Church's stance on abortion will change. Such affairs are not within my province. I will only have difficulties with the Church when it intrudes into the private business and sexual lives of women who are not Roman Catholics--as it presently does.
ResponseText: HUH?! Vacillated on abortion? Don't hold your breath waiting for the Catholic Church to change its mind on abortion. You may see some changes towards more females occupying traditional male roles within the Church, though. I don't think that the Catholic Church views morality as strictly a Catholic responsibility.

QuoteText: female roles wont change it....It is a set of beliefs not a sex that determines how you feel about abortion. My beloved Episcopal Church does not support abortion and I have a female rector.
ResponseText: And, you are not female, will never be pregnant, will never have to make a decision about pregnancy.

QuoteText: . . . . I don't think that the Catholic Church views morality as strictly a Catholic responsibility.
ResponseText: I don't think that abortion is a moral issue. And, I shan't have the moral views of the Roman Catholic Church imposed upon me. I insist upon my right to my own moral and religious freedom, I will not be subject to a foreign entity that does not view women with respect.

QuoteText: And, you are not female, will never be pregnant, will never have to make a decision about pregnancy.

ResponseText: You will never see the issue of abortion as a woman does--as a woman who could be pregnant, who has been pregnant--will see it.
so I can't have an opinion on it or something? I guess one could say a women will never see it from a mans perspective.

QuoteText: You will never see the issue of abortion as a woman does--as a woman who could be pregnant, who has been pregnant--will see it.
ResponseText: Ah, the old "walk a mile in my shoe" argument. I guess I can't recognize racial discrimination unless I'm black, recognize age discrimination unless I'm old, etc., etc., Tired old argument.

Of course men can, do, and should have opinions and feelings about abortion, but to say that your interest is equal to that as a woman is silly. Men will never be pregnant, regardless of what laws stand, they impact men very little in any real way.
I don't believe that to be true either. My interest is more so then my girlfriends. hehe.
